bibl.title: Nāgārjuna's Reason Sixty
bibl.author: Loizzo, Joseph, and the AIBS Team

sentence.phrase: Sixty Stanzas of Reasonings
Homage to the Ever-youthful Mañjuśrī!
I pay homage to that Lord of Sages
Who proclaimed dependent arising,
The means by which he abandonned
Creation and destruction!
Those whose intellects transcend
Being and nothingness, and do not dwell [in between],
Meditate on the meaning of conditions,
Which is profound and unobservable.
Those who have turned away from nihilism
The source of all ills,
Should attend to the reasons why
The extreme of permanence should be rejected as well.
If things were real
As the childish construe them,
Then why not accept
Nothing[ness] as liberation?
One cannot be liberated through the extreme of permanence,
Nor transcend this existence through nihilism;
The great beings are liberated
By comprehending being and nothingness.
Those who do not see reality presume
The world and nirvāṇa;
Those who see reality do not presume
Either a world nor transcendence.
Existence and nirvāṇa —
Neither of those two are existent;
Complete comprehension of existence
Is what is called “nirvāṇa.”
[The childish] imagine cessation
As the annihilation of a created being,
While the wise understand it
As like the cessation of a magician’s illusion.
If cessation came by destruction, [and]
Not by cognizing the contingent,
Who would there be to directly perceive it?
What would such a destroyed [person] be like?
[Some claim:] “If the aggregates have not ceased,
Though afflictions have stopped, there is no transcendence;
When one’s [aggregates] have ceased
Then [and only then] would one be liberated.”
When one sees with correct intuition
What occurs conditioned by misknowledge,
One does not perceive anything
That could possibly be created or cease.
At [the moment of] the truth of seeing [suchness, one achieves] nirvāṇa;
[It is] the accomplishment of the objective, or suchness.
If, after such [direct] insight into the [Four Noble] Truths,
One finds distinctions in this [object of realization],
Imagining anything, however subtle,
That could be created,
Such an unwise individual
Has not seen the meaning of dependent arising.
If monks who exhaust their afflictions
Completely overturn cyclic life,
Then why do the perfect Buddhas
Not explain the beginning of that [cyclic life]?
If there were a beginning, then there would be faults,
and one would be obsessed with [false] worldviews.
What beginning or end could there be
To that which arises dependently?
How could something previously [absolutely] created
Later be eliminated?
Free from initial or terminal limits,
The [places of] migration appear like illusions.
When an illusion arises
Or when it is destroyed,
One who knows the illusion is not confused;
One ignorant of the illusion is entranced by it.
One whose intellect sees existence
As analogous to an illusion or mirage,
Is not deceived by [extremist] views
Of an ultimate beginning or end.
Those who imagine that contingent things
Are [intrinsically] created and destroyed,
Utterly fail to understand
The turning of the wheel of dependent arising.
What arises, dependent upon this and that
Is not intrinsically created;
How can one call the intrinsically
Uncreated, “created?”
Peace through exhausting the causes [of suffering]
Manifests as so-called “termination;”
How can one call the intrinsically
Unterminated, “terminated”?
Thus, nothing whatsoever is created;
And nothing whatsoever will cease.
The path of creation and destruction
Was taught for a meaningful purpose:
By knowing creation, one knows destruction;
By knowing destruction, one knows impermanence.
Through knowing the entry into impermanence,
One will come, as well, to realize the truth.
Those who develop insight
Into dependent arising,
And abandon creation and destruction,
Cross the ocean of existence with its [bad] views.
Alienated beings, who hold the self [to be] real,
Are mistaken about existence and non-existence, and
Because of [such] faults, come under the influence of afflictions,
Are deceived by their own minds.
Those who are expert in things
See things as impermanent,
Deceptive in nature, worthless,
Empty, selfless, and [hence,] isolated.
Without a supporting [condition], an observed object does not exist;
There is no root, and there is no support,
Utterly arisen from the cause — misknowledge —
Bereft of beginning, middle, and end.
Essenceless — like a plantain [tree] —
Resembling an ephemeral city
And an unbearable city of confusion,
Lifeforms appear like illusions.
Since what is proclaimed as truth
In this world by Brahma [the Creator] and others,
The noble ones call “false.”
What remains that is other than this?
How can the worldly, blinded by misknowledge [and]
Followers of [their own] continuum of existence,
And the virtuous, who are skilled and
Free of craving, be viewed as equal?
As a means [of entering] reality, at first
One should declare “everything exists;”
Once they have understood things and are attached [to them],
Thereafter, [one may teach] the isolation [of things].
Ignorant of the meaning of isolation,
Those who act out of merely what they have heard
Neglect the exercise of virtue;
Such sorry creatures are lost.
[The Buddha] discussed the existence of the effects of actions,
As well as the forms of life [they give rise to];
[He] taught the thorough undertstanding of their nature,
Including their uncreatedness.
Just as the Victors say “I”
And “mine” for a reason,
So they speak of “aggregates,” “media,”
And “elements,” for a reason.
Explanations of the primary elements and so forth
Are subsumed within consciousness,
For when the consciousness becomes separated from that [object],
Is it not a false construction?
“Nirvāṇa is the sole truth,”
Is what the Victors declared;
Then, what expert would not realize,
“Everything else is false”?
Just as long as the mind vacillates,
For just so long, [it remains under] the dominion of Māra.
When that is the case, then how is it even on this [occasion],
That without any faults, it is unacceptable?
“By the condition of misknowledge, there is the world,”
As the perfect Buddha says.
Hence, how is it incorrect to say that
Even these worlds are “[mere mental] constructions”?
That which ceases
when ignorance ceases —
All of that is constructed from ignorance.
Therefore, why would it not be cleared away?
Whatever has originated from an existent cause
Cannot endure without [sustaining] conditions,
And in the absence of conditions, moreover, disintegrates;
How can one consider such [a thing really] to exist?
When those who espouse [objective] existence
Maintain their insistence on [objectively existent] things,
And remain on that very path,
It is not surprising in the least.
For those who, having relied on the path of the Buddha,
Advocate the impermanence of all things,
To maintain any sort of attachment to [real] things
With arguments, that is amazing!
If, having analyzed something [designated] “this” or “that,”
[An intrinsically identifiable referent] is utterly unseen
What wise person would make the argument
“‘This’ or ‘that’ is true”?
Those without a [rational] basis,
Addicted to a “self” or the “world,”
Alas! They are captivated
By views of permanence and impermanence, etc.
Wishing to establish in reality
Things as having depended upon some [other things],
How can one not come to develop the problems of
[Holding views] such as absolutism towards these [things]?
Those who accept things as having depended upon
Some [other things], like the moon in water —
As neither [intrinsically] real nor unreal —
Are not captivated by views.
Once they have assertions of things,
They maintain intolerable, malignant views,
Which generate attachment and aversion,
And the disputes that spring from them.
That is the cause of all views;
Without it, afflictions could not develop.
So when it's [falsity] is fully known,
Worldviews and afflictions are fully cured.
Someone asks, “How is this to be known?”
See dependent arising —
Know the dependently created to be uncreated.
So the supreme omniscient [Buddha] proclaimed.
Those overwhelmed by mistaken knowledge
Grasp at true [existence] in what is not truly [existent];
Hence the sequence of clinging, disputes,
And so forth, springs from attachment [to things as truly existent].
The great beings have no disputes, [and]
Have no position.
For those who have no position,
How can there be any opposed position?
Having found any possible place,
The cunning, poisonous snake of compulsion
Will seize it; those whose minds
Have no [such] place are not seized.
How could the venom of afflictions not arise
For those whose minds hold a place for it?
While ordinary beings abide [in that state],
The snake of the afflictions will seize them.
Since the childish conceive of [things] as truly [existent]
Like being attached to a reflection,
Worldly people, due to delusion
Are trapped in the thicket of objects.
Seeing with their wisdom-eye
That things are like reflections,
The [noble] great beings do not get stuck
In the mire of objects.
The childish are attached to forms, [while]
The average are free from attachment to them, [but]
Those with the highest intelligence who know
The [true] nature of forms are liberated.
Those who hold suffering as something dear, are attached;
Those who turn away from it are free of desirous attachment.
But those who see it in isolation,
As like an illusory person, reach nirvāṇa.
Those tormented by false knowledge
Have all the faults of the afflictions;
Yet, having conceived of being and nothingness
When one has become fully cognizant, [they] do not arise.
When one has a place [for them], one perceives
Attachment and freedom from attachment;
But the great beings, having no [such] place,
Are neither attached nor free from attachment.
Whosoever isolates [things from intrinsic existence]
And does not vacillate with a wavering mind
Will cross the ocean of intolerable existence,
Which seethes with the snakes of the afflictions.
By the virtue [arisen from writing this] may all beings
Gather the stores of merit and wisdom,
And attain the two supreme [buddha bodies]
Arisen from merit and wisdom!
So ends the Sixty Stanza on Reasonings composed by the Master, the lineage-holder, the Ārya Nāgārjuna.
This version was prepared by the Tibetan translator Pa-tshab Nyi-ma-grags under the direction of the lineage master and Indian Abbot Muditaśrī.
